full_text: Succeed Insurance has specified that, if at least a third of the persons in the work group are on vacation, which should not happen very often, then that group will not be assigned any new claims. This rule should not apply to groups with less than three persons. In Studio, I navigate to the rule sets. The appropriate triggering event is exception. Exception rules target claims, activities, users, and groups that need some type of special attention. Activity exception rules run automatically when an activity is escalated. Let's look at a typical activity exception rule. For example, this rule becomes active when the priority of an escalated activity is high. When this happens, it sets a flag on the activity. Conversely, claim, group, and user exception rules operate on a schedule. When they run, they scan for conditions that may apply to any given claim, group, or user. For example, if there is an open claim, where the claims assign user does not have any open activities assigned to them. Then this rule will create an activity for the user to review the claim. I need to automatically create an activity based on the vacation status of the users in a group, so I will create a group exception rule. In the default configuration, these rules are checked daily at 4 am. There are no group exception rules in the default configuration. I will create a new one.  I will leave the default condition of true, so that every group will be checked every night. The group is already available as a parameter. The first thing I need is the number of users on vacation. I will derive it from the properties of the group. I will need to compare that number to one third the number of users in the group. I will also check to make sure that there are at least three members in the group. Bye! Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

segments.text: Succeed Insurance has specified that, if at least a third of the persons in the work group are on vacation, which should not happen very often, then that group will not be assigned any new claims. This rule should not apply to groups with less than three persons. In Studio, I navigate to the rule sets.
The appropriate triggering event is exception. Exception rules target claims, activities, users, and groups that need some type of special attention.
Activity exception rules run automatically when an activity is escalated. Let's look at a typical activity exception rule.
For example, this rule becomes active when the priority of an escalated activity is high. When this happens, it sets a flag on the activity.
Conversely, claim, group, and user exception rules operate on a schedule. When they run, they scan for conditions that may apply to any given claim, group, or user.
For example, if there is an open claim, where the claims assign user does not have any open activities assigned to them. Then this rule will create an activity for the user to review the claim.
I need to automatically create an activity based on the vacation status of the users in a group, so I will create a group exception rule.
In the default configuration, these rules are checked daily at 4 am. There are no group exception rules in the default configuration.
I will create a new one.

I will leave the default condition of true, so that every group will be checked every night. The group is already available as a parameter. The first thing I need is the number of users on vacation. I will derive it from the properties of the group.
I will need to compare that number to one third the number of users in the group.
I will also check to make sure that there are at least three members in the group.
